title: Interfaces In Java
summary: Interfaces are used to specify an expected behavior of an object. Java does not support inheritance for Interfaces. Interfaces define only static fields, which belong to the interface and are the same for all instances of the same interface. Classes that implement the interfaces will inherit their functionality but not their implementation. This means that any code that implements an interface can change its implementation as much as it wants, as long as it follows the specification of the interface. Using interfaces is also a great way to break up your code into small, reusable pieces.
